title: Trump Rings In New Year By Promising Big Reveal Of Inside Info On ‘Russian Hacking’
text:
Dems Show Their True Colors With SICK Move They’ve Prepared For Trump: ‘Any Attempt…’ 
Speaking to reporters on New Year’s Eve, the president-elect said that he wants intelligence agencies to be absolutely certain Russia was behind the attacks on Democrats. 
“I just want them to be sure, because it’s a pretty serious charge, and I want them to be sure,” Trump said, before taking a shot at intelligence leading up to the Iraq War: “And if you look at the weapons of mass destruction, that was a disaster, and they were wrong. And so I want them to be sure.” 
“I think it’s unfair if they don’t know. And I know a lot about hacking. And hacking is a very hard thing to prove. So it could be somebody else. And I also know things that other people don’t know, and so they cannot be sure of the situation,” Trump added, according to the New York Post . Advertisement - story continues below 
Meanwhile, Trump’s incoming White House press secretary, Sean Spicer, said Monday that the reports of Russian meddling and intrusions into Democrat email accounts were being given too much attention by the media. 
“Whether or not they were hacked, and [Russians] did anything, is a completely different story. The way the mainstream media is playing this up is that they had an influence in the election,” Spicer said, according to the U.K. Daily Mail . “There is zero evidence that they actually influenced the election.” 
Lack of evidence didn’t stop the media from breathlessly reporting on the latest Russian hacking “scare,” this time up in Vermont. The Washington Post reported on New Year’s Eve that the Russians had managed to hack into the U.S. electrical grid via a Vermont utility. The story was reported across the media with dire urgency. 
Then, The Washington Post’s correction/ retraction was covered with considerably less urgency: Editor’s Note : An earlier version of this story incorrectly said that Russian hackers had penetrated the U.S. electric grid. Authorities say there is no indication of that so far. The computer at Burlington Electric that was hacked was not attached to the grid. Advertisement - story continues below
